column6: description

The first newsletter discusses changes to the town of McGill including the purchase of the bank building by Mike Nass, a new salon, restoration of the I.O.O.F. Hall and the refurbishment of the sheriff's office and post office.
In addition, there is an informative section on the McGill Water Carnival.
Memorial Day is celebrated and Mike Nass's new business takes shape in the former bank building.
June 6th, 1944 (D-Day) is discussed as is the progression of the I.O.O.F Hall restoration.
Discussion regarding the return of the trees on the mountain, completion of the new cell tower as well as the archery shooting event.
The town-wide yard sale and continued restoration of the I.O.O.F. Hall is discussed. Images of the ongoing restoration are included.

The 4th of July issue for 2019. The McGill Grade School band (under the direction of John Mulvehill) is shown in a vintage photo from 1952. The combined band of the McGill Grade School and Ruth Grade School is shown in a 1946 or 1947 photo.
This edition showcases a fun community center event as well as 4th of July parade photos.
McGill experienced a quiet week with the local firemen cooking up a delicious BBQ. Keith gives a tip on the best BBQ wood to use!

McGill heats up! As the weather grew warmer, McGill residents took to the local pool to stay cool. This version contains nice images of the pool as well as a couple historic images of Main Street in the 1920's.
Interesting story on the possible origin of a rock wall near Duck Creek. Historic photo of the annual rabbit hunt from 1908. What a way to spend the day after Christmas!
A tragic head-on car collision in 1933 kills four people. A brief rainstorm in 2019 causes flooding to local businesses.
The talented Bristlecone Quilters show off their quilts at the high school gym. Main Street receives new paving. An image from Main Street circa 1908 is included.

This issues talks of the declining sports opportunities for the youngsters. In its early years, McGill's youth had many activities to keep them busing including baseball, football, hiking and more. The upcoming McGill Birthday and Picnic is also discussed.

Titled "McGill, Over the Years" this issue showcases some of the changes McGill kids experienced in the late 1940 through the 1950's. Sports were encouraged and kids eagerly participated. Current-day McGill gets a new slurry coat to main street.

White Pine County celebrates a music festival in 1950. Titled the "Music Clinic Festival", each school would put on a show in hopes of impressing out-of-state music critics. Current-day McGill experiences hot weather, the annual parade and street dance as well as photos of the 1922 mill fire.

Community Pride!  Lack of modern conveniences such as TV and cell phones caused McGill residents to seek entertainment in much more sociable ways. Parades, sports and music competitions were mainstream and instilled a sense of pride in the community. The 2019 McGill birthday takes place with a subdued parade followed by the BBQ and Pool Splash event.

Keith discusses the Friday the 13th superstition and McGillites experience increased traffic.  An image is shown of the old McGill housing structure constructed by Kennecott for single women teachers.

Like all small counties, White Pine has it's cast of characters that are remembered even today. This edition reveals some of the more colorful ones! Present-day McGill experiences cooler weather. The Drugstore attracts some interesting visitors - some international. Vintage photos of the smelter, power house and its smokestacks.
Labor Day memories and images of Union leaders and members.

Odd things in old trunks! Keith shares memories and an image of his grandmother, Martha Gibson, and his aunt (Pearl Lee) who played for the McGill women's baseball team in (approximately) the early 1900's. Keith donates a postcard of an amusement park (in Butte, Montana) which was destroyed in a suspicious fire. In present -day McGill, Mike Nass, opens the first U-Haul drop-off business.
Odd things in trunks - Part 2! Keith finds another interesting image to donate to a Kansas museum. Present-day McGill prepares for the upcoming Halloween party.
Keith talks about the first phone system in McGill. Since use of the new system was limited, boys learned to construct their own means of communication via string and paper oatmeal boxes.

Keith finds a photo of an Army tank with a hand-written note from his father, Bud Gibson. The tank was brought to McGill in 1919 as a show of US Army strength as well as to promote war bonds. Many McGill residents are in the photo. Mention of the 2019 McGill Halloween party.

A vintage image of a molten slag car. Slag being the byproduct created during metal smelting. Keith recalls stories his father told him about his days working at the smelter. Mike Nass opens his locksmith shop and the event is attended by the McGill town council.

A former employee of the McGill Drugstore makes a nostalgic return! Beverly Crawforth worked at the Drugstore in the mid 40's and was Keith's neighbor as well. Beverly is in her 90's and was accompanied by her son and daughters. The town celebrated Beverly's birthday with an impromptu party complete with cake!

Images of several McGill gas stations through the decades. The present-day McGill Antique store is featured with lots of fantastic items for sale! Vintage images of the mill fire (circa 1922) are included.

A 1909 image of the building that houses present-day McGill Antique's is included. Several of the images are missing dates, but estimates dates range from the 20's to the early 60's. Keith visits the library and has an odd experience.

The holiday season of 1941 began with a memorable Thanksgiving. Two weeks later The attack on Pearl Harbor occurred. Present-day McGill experiences light snowfall and the town begins to install Christmas decorations.

The KCC Commissary and Boarding House (built in 1924-1925) is pictured. Kennicott issued coupon books to workers which were paid through their next payroll check. Workers could purchase clothing, food and other items. The building was replaced by a gas station in 1960. The Drugstore got a VIP in November of 2019. John Glenn (yes, the Astronaut) visited the store and made favorable comments.

Images of the roaster stack being destroyed in 1929. The roaster (and stack) was rendered obsolete as the mill was able to supply a larger amount of copper concentrate to the smelter. Present-day McGill readies for the Christmas parade and the roof on the theater is finally finished!
The annual Christmas parade takes place and is a huge success! Residents enjoy the holiday-themed light posts decorated in honor of Rose Papez. Keith shares a memory of a Christmas past.

Keith recalls past New Year's celebrations and parties. The annual Fireman's Ball was one of the biggest events in the town. Keith thanks those McGill residents who make Christmas a success by putting in long hours to ensure packages and goods are delivered on time.
First McGill Phone System
column9: The first phone and switching unit in McGill was housed under the assy office.

column6: The McGill Post Office, circa 1891. Located on property owned by William McGill, the first postmistress was his daughter, Kate McGill.

column6: Tents were constructed as early housing for mine employees. They were later replaced by simple wooden structures.

column6: The company had a young McGill resident pull the trigger to demolish one of the obsolete stacks.
